title: How to Make Poke Nachos

steps.headline: Dice the tuna into ½-inch (1.27-centimeter) pieces.
steps.description: Even though tuna is one of the safer types of fish to consume raw, you should still use high-quality tuna meant for sushi or sashimi. If you are not certain if the tuna you are buying is sushi-grade, ask the person at the counter.

steps.headline: Combine the tuna with the onion, lime juice, and soy sauce.
steps.description: Place the tuna into a medium-sized bowl. Add the diced onion, lime juice, and soy sauce. Toss the ingredients together to mix, then set them aside. The tuna will soak up the lime juice and soy sauce and become more flavorful.

steps.headline: Prepare the dressing.
steps.description: Measure ¾ cup (174 grams) of mayonnaise into a small mixing bowl. Add 2 tablespoons (30 milliliters) of Sriracha. Whisk the two together until the color is even and no streaks remain. Set the dressing aside as well.

steps.headline: Start layering your ingredients.
steps.description: Spread half of the tortilla chips across a serving platter. Distribute half of the tuna over the chips. Add half of the radishes, avocado, jalapeños, and cilantro.

steps.headline: Drizzle half of the dressing over the nachos.
steps.description: Use a spoon or a sauce ladle to scoop up the dressing, and then drizzle it across the nachos in a zigzag. Save the rest for later.

steps.headline: Repeat your layers one more time.
steps.description: Spread the rest of the chips and tuna on top. Add the remaining radishes, avocado, jalapeño, and cilantro. This is the final layer, so you can scatter the ingredients randomly, or arrange them in a more artistic fashion. For example, you could overlap the radishes in a circle to make them look like a flower.

steps.headline: Finish off the nachos.
steps.description: Drizzle the rest of your dressing over the nachos. This is the final topping, so you can drizzle the dressing randomly or in a design, such as a spiral or zigzag.

steps.headline: Serve the nachos.
steps.description: Slice a lime into wedges, and arrange them around the edges of the platter. You can also place them into a separate bowl or dish as well.

steps.headline: Prepare the oil and wonton wrappers for frying.
steps.description: Fill a large pot with 2 quarts (2 liters) of frying oil. Heat it over medium heat to 350°F (177°C). As the oil heats up, cut the wonton wrappers in half diagonally to get triangles.

steps.headline: Fry the wontons 4 to 6 at a time for 1 to 2 minutes.
steps.description: Drop 4 to 6 wonton triangles into the pot. Let them fry for 1 to 2 minutes. When they turn golden brown, take them out with a pair of tongs and set them down on a paper towel.

steps.headline: Sprinkle the fried wontons with salt.
steps.description: Continue frying the rest of the wontons, 4 to 6 at a time for 1 to 2 minutes. If the wontons start to turn too dark, the oil is too hot. Lower the temperature on the stove, wait for the oil to cool back down to 350°F (177°C), and continue frying. Don't try to cram all of the nachos onto one paper towel. Use another one if you have to.

steps.headline: Prepare the mango salsa.
steps.description: Fill a mixing bowl with 1 cup (256 grams) of salsa or pico de gallo. Peel, pit, and dice a ripe mango and add it into the bowl. Stir everything together with a spoon. For extra kick, add in some Sriracha or other hot sauce.

steps.headline: Prepare the dressing.
steps.description: Measure ½ cup (116 grams) of mayonnaise into a separate mixing bowl. Add 1 tablespoon (22.5 grams) of honey and 1 teaspoon of wasabi paste. Stir everything together with a whisk until the color is even and there are no streaks. Give the dressing a taste, and stir in some salt, if needed.

steps.headline: Cut the tuna lengthwise into two steaks.
steps.description: Even though you will be searing the tuna, you still want to use high-quality tuna meant for sushi or sashimi. Ask the person at the counter if you are uncertain of the tuna's quality.

steps.headline: Season the tuna.
steps.description: Sprinkle both sides of each tuna steak with salt and pepper. Pour the sesame seeds into a plate or dish. Press the tuna steaks into the steaks, flip them over, and press again.

steps.headline: Sear the tuna steaks.
steps.description: Heat a skillet over high heat. Place the tuna steaks onto the skillet, and sear them for 1 minute. Flip them over with a spatula or a pair of tongs, and sear them for another minute. Do not oil the skillet. Do not overcook the tuna. You want the inside to still be raw while the outside is cooked.

steps.headline: Dice the tuna.
steps.description: Once the tuna is seared, transfer it to a cutting board. Let it cool down enough to handle, then use a sharp knife to cut it into ½-inch (1.27-centimeter) cubes.

steps.headline: Assemble the nachos.
steps.description: Spread the wonton chips across a large serving platter. Add the shredded cabbage on top, followed by the mango salsa. Scatter the seared ahi tuna on top, then top it off with some avocado slices. You can dice the avocado instead of slicing it.

steps.headline: Drizzle the sauce over the nachos before serving them.
steps.description: Use a spoon or sauce ladle to scoop up the sauce. Drizzle it over the nachos. You can do a random pattern, a zigzag, or even a swirl. Serve the nachos immediately.

text: Making Basic Poke Nachos Dice the tuna into ½-inch (1.27-centimeter) pieces. Even though tuna is one of the safer types of fish to consume raw, you should still use high-quality tuna meant for sushi or sashimi. If you are not certain if the tuna you are buying is sushi-grade, ask the person at the counter. Combine the tuna with the onion, lime juice, and soy sauce. Place the tuna into a medium-sized bowl. Add the diced onion, lime juice, and soy sauce. Toss the ingredients together to mix, then set them aside. The tuna will soak up the lime juice and soy sauce and become more flavorful. Prepare the dressing. Measure ¾ cup (174 grams) of mayonnaise into a small mixing bowl. Add 2 tablespoons (30 milliliters) of Sriracha. Whisk the two together until the color is even and no streaks remain. Set the dressing aside as well. Start layering your ingredients. Spread half of the tortilla chips across a serving platter. Distribute half of the tuna over the chips. Add half of the radishes, avocado, jalapeños, and cilantro. Drizzle half of the dressing over the nachos. Use a spoon or a sauce ladle to scoop up the dressing, and then drizzle it across the nachos in a zigzag. Save the rest for later. Repeat your layers one more time. Spread the rest of the chips and tuna on top. Add the remaining radishes, avocado, jalapeño, and cilantro. This is the final layer, so you can scatter the ingredients randomly, or arrange them in a more artistic fashion. For example, you could overlap the radishes in a circle to make them look like a flower. Finish off the nachos. Drizzle the rest of your dressing over the nachos. This is the final topping, so you can drizzle the dressing randomly or in a design, such as a spiral or zigzag. Serve the nachos. Slice a lime into wedges, and arrange them around the edges of the platter. You can also place them into a separate bowl or dish as well. Making Asian-Inspired Poke Nachos Prepare the oil and wonton wrappers for frying. Fill a large pot with 2 quarts (2 liters) of frying oil. Heat it over medium heat to 350°F (177°C). As the oil heats up, cut the wonton wrappers in half diagonally to get triangles. Fry the wontons 4 to 6 at a time for 1 to 2 minutes. Drop 4 to 6 wonton triangles into the pot. Let them fry for 1 to 2 minutes. When they turn golden brown, take them out with a pair of tongs and set them down on a paper towel. Sprinkle the fried wontons with salt. Continue frying the rest of the wontons, 4 to 6 at a time for 1 to 2 minutes. If the wontons start to turn too dark, the oil is too hot. Lower the temperature on the stove, wait for the oil to cool back down to 350°F (177°C), and continue frying. Don't try to cram all of the nachos onto one paper towel. Use another one if you have to. Prepare the mango salsa. Fill a mixing bowl with 1 cup (256 grams) of salsa or pico de gallo. Peel, pit, and dice a ripe mango and add it into the bowl. Stir everything together with a spoon. For extra kick, add in some Sriracha or other hot sauce. Prepare the dressing. Measure ½ cup (116 grams) of mayonnaise into a separate mixing bowl. Add 1 tablespoon (22.5 grams) of honey and 1 teaspoon of wasabi paste. Stir everything together with a whisk until the color is even and there are no streaks. Give the dressing a taste, and stir in some salt, if needed. Cut the tuna lengthwise into two steaks. Even though you will be searing the tuna, you still want to use high-quality tuna meant for sushi or sashimi. Ask the person at the counter if you are uncertain of the tuna's quality. Season the tuna. Sprinkle both sides of each tuna steak with salt and pepper. Pour the sesame seeds into a plate or dish. Press the tuna steaks into the steaks, flip them over, and press again. Sear the tuna steaks. Heat a skillet over high heat. Place the tuna steaks onto the skillet, and sear them for 1 minute. Flip them over with a spatula or a pair of tongs, and sear them for another minute. Do not oil the skillet. Do not overcook the tuna. You want the inside to still be raw while the outside is cooked. Dice the tuna. Once the tuna is seared, transfer it to a cutting board. Let it cool down enough to handle, then use a sharp knife to cut it into ½-inch (1.27-centimeter) cubes. Assemble the nachos. Spread the wonton chips across a large serving platter. Add the shredded cabbage on top, followed by the mango salsa. Scatter the seared ahi tuna on top, then top it off with some avocado slices. You can dice the avocado instead of slicing it. Drizzle the sauce over the nachos before serving them. Use a spoon or sauce ladle to scoop up the sauce. Drizzle it over the nachos. You can do a random pattern, a zigzag, or even a swirl. Serve the nachos immediately.
